acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2 from its 24h-EC50 = 1.6 mg/L for Crustacea (Daphnia magna) (AQUIRE, 2010).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on a LC50 value of 21,000 mg/m3/2h (2133 ppm/4h) for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 3. Since the report of the vapour was in the assessment document, the classification criteria for gas was adopted.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 2.7 g/kg for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into "Not classified" in JIS Classification (corresponding to Category 5 in GHS classification).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2 since its acute toxicity is Category 2 and it is not rapidly degradable (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1982).

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified into Category 3 since flash point 51 degC (closed-cup) (Hommel (1996)) is >=23 degC and <=60 degC. The substance is classified into Class 3, PG III in UNRTDG (UN2514).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data from in vivo mutagenicity tests. From in vitro mutagenicity tests, there are reports of a negative Ames test and a negative Chinese hamster ovary cells chromosomal aberration test (NTP DB (access on Aug. 2009)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is 565 degC (Chapman (Ver. 17.1, 2009)) exceeding 70 degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on reports of irritating for the skin (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and irritant to skin (HSDB (2003)), and classification as Xi; R38 in EU classification (EU-Annex I (access on Aug. 2009)), the substance was classified into Category 2

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It is reported that the substance shows biological activity (toxicity) through conversion by oxidative metabolic process related to metabolic enzyme in the liver and enhances the hepatotoxicity by induction of microsomal enzymes (PATTY (5th, 2001)). It is also reported that the metabolites can be found in the areas of hepatic centrilobular necrosis induced by the substance (HSDB (2003)). In addition, there is a report that exposure of rats to 0.02 - 0.25 mg/L for 4.5-month caused disorders of liver function and inhibition of nervous system (HSDB (2003)). Although these effects correspond to Category 1 based on guidance value range, the substance was classified into Category 2 (liver, nervous system) because of information in List 2 and non-meeting Decision criteria 1b 3).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: It is noted that the substance shows biological activity (toxicity) through conversion by an oxidative metabolic process related to a metabolic enzyme in the liver and enhances the hepatotoxicity by induction of microsomal enzymes (PATTY (5th, 2001)). It is also reported that the metabolites can be found in the areas of hepatic centrilobular necrosis induced by the substance (HSDB (2003)). Rats orally administered at 3 g/kg showed widespread hepatic necrosis not only around centrilobular veins but also around all tributaries of the hepatic veins (HSDB (2003)). In addition, in an acute oral toxicity test with rats at levels of 2000 - 4000 mg/kg, clinical observations included lacrimation, chromodacryorrhea, stained perineal area, stained face, tremors, weakness, and lethargy (HSDB (2003)). Since these findings were observed at a dose level exceeding the guidance value range and effects at the approximate cut-off value are not clear due to lack of data, classification was not possible.
